She has accumulated a small amount of money and has started building but, unfortunately, she doesn't have enough money to buy all the materials for this construction. She is applying for a loan in the sum of USD 1,200 to buy timber, roofing, and floorboards for the completion of her house. She really appreciates all the help she will get from Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy timber, roofing, and floorboards for the completion of her house.

loans.name: Buenaventurada

texts.en:
Buenaventurada works hard to support her family. She is married and has a recycled materials retail business in the Philippines.

Buenaventurada requested a PHP 11000 loan through NWTF to buy recycled materials to sell.

She has been in this business for five years and also earns additional income from a general store.

In the future, Buenaventurada would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy recycled materials to sell

loans.name: Revelita

texts.en:
Patience and dedication has been Revelita's guiding principle for the smooth flow of her construction supply business.She is now 64 years of age, married with eight children. She is really blessed because all her children are professionals.

Revelita's business involvement is selling construction supplies, kitchen utensils and home appliances. She doesn't have her own stall to store the products she offers.  She prefers instead a made to order strategy in selling her products. With her marketing strategy, she is able to earn a better income which serves to provide their daily household expenses, medication for her husband and their savings. Revelita aspires to a continuous improvement of her financial stability and increased sales so that she could make it a stable source of her family income.

Revelita's business grows smoothly but due to many orders, she struggles with a shortage of capital. She is seeking capital in the amount of PHP40,000. This amount will be used in buying a washing machine, galvanized iron, hollow blocks and cement for her construction supply business. She hopes and prays that her business will continue to develop.

loans.use: to buy a washing machine, galvanized iron, hollow blocks and cement for her construction supply business

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is 43 years old and married with four children. She lives in a rental house in Tiribe, Kenya with her husband and four children. Her major monthly expenditures are school fees and rent.

She is a hardworking entrepreneur and she owns a fish stall where she fries fish before selling them to consumers at retail price. She has requested a loan amounting to ksh.20000 in order to buy fish in large quantity and resell them since the demand is increasing regularly.

loans.use: to buy fish in large quantity for resale

loans.name: Basilisa

texts.en: This time, for her sixth loan, Basilisa is borrowing 10000 PHP to purchase more groceries to sell at her store. Her general store business that was previously funded through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc and Kiva continues to provide for Basilisa and her family with income that is improving their standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Stellamaris

texts.en:
Stellamaris is a married woman who lives in Likoni with her husband and two children. She is a very friendly, hardworking and enthusiastic person who has a desire to succeed. 

Stellamaris works in her small store selling clothes. She is extremely grateful to the Kiva lenders as it is thanks to the help given that she will be able buy a larger volume of merchandise such as clothing, decorations and other items. In this way, Stellamaris will have a business that is better set up, and so she will continue working and make every effort to achieve her greatest dream of having her own boutique.

loans.use: to buy a larger volume of merchandise such as clothing and decorations.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is 30 years old and married with two children. She lives in Tiribe, Kenya. She is enterprising, hardworking and committed to the goals that she has set to accomplish.

She has had a grocery store in her home and thanks to the quality, the good prices and the service, people prefer her and they have a dependable source for their purchases. She has been in the business for two years. She wants to buy more supplies so she can increase the production and thus the sales, but she does not have enough capital to do it. This is why she is requesting a loan amounting to 10,000 Kenyan shillings to buy sacks of potatoes and vegetables. She has a good credit history.

loans.use: to buy sacks of potatoes and vegetables.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en: Mwanamisi is applying for a new loan, after successful repayment of the previous loan. She is grateful that the previous loan helped her to expand her market territory. Now, she is requesting a loan in the amount of KES 10,000 to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.name: Leo

texts.en:
Leo lives with his wife and three children, at the village of Namillangan Alfonso Lista. Leo's and his wife's main priority is to earn more income, so they can sustain their children's education, meet their daily needs, and improve their living conditions. Leo is a hog raiser and a farmer.

Leo would like to ensure the proper growth of his hogs until they reach their optimum size. For this reason, he is asking for a loan of PHP 50,000. The loan will enable him to buy necessary hog feed, vaccines and essential vitamins, for his livestock business. Leo believes that his hogs will gain weight by using the proper livestock supplies for them. In this way, he may earn better income, which will enable him to secure his family's future.

loans.use: to buy more hog feed, vaccines and essential vitamins, for his livestock business

loans.name: Hamida

texts.en:
Hamida lives in Likoni with her husband and three children. She started her business four years ago because she needed to sustain her household but was not earning an income. For this reason, she began investing in the sale of charcoal.

One obstacle is that she does not have a place for her merchandise. Since her business is located in her home, this proves to be a bit difficult. She works alone without having support from anyone. As a result, she can earn more income to pay for her household expenses.

With this loan, Hamida will buy sacks of charcoal for resale. In the end, she will have more income and more customers.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is a 39-year-old farmer in Nkubu county in Kenya, where she lives with her husband and three children. Her children are all in school. She has been farming for the past 11 years, producing milk, mangoes, bananas and maize, which she sells at a nearby market in her area.

She is requesting a loan for 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow, which will help her increase her income, boost her living standards and provide school fees for her children's education. She hopes to open a milk bar, since she will have more milk produced to boost her income in the next five years.

Rosemary says that she believes her business will grow through getting a loan from Juhudi Kilimo.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a married woman. She has been in the clothing business for the last seven years. She buys clothes of different varieties from the city and sells them in her local community. She earns enough profit through her business to contribute well to the family income. Her husband is a businessman, but his income alone is not sufficient to meet the needs of the family members.

Amina is a mother of one child and is motivated to provide for her family. For the improvement of her business, she contacted Yehu Microfinance and applied for a loan of 40,000 KES. She intends to utilize this loan amount to purchase a greater variety of clothes in different colors and designs, taking into account the tastes and choices of her customers. In this way she will be able to increase her sales, which will ultimately help in generating more cash.

loans.use: to purchase a greater variety of clothes in different colors and designs for resale

loans.name: Mujeres Sobresalientes Group

texts.es:
El comité “Mujeres Sobresalientes”  están  en el Tercer ciclo, con 16  integrantes, es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unidas, solidarias  y responsables, ellas tienen actividades diferentes.
Una de las miembros es la Sra. Clotilde, quien es una excelente modista, y por medio de su trabajo está saliendo adelante, ella es una persona que desde siempre ha trabajado y no teme luchar por dar a su familia todo lo que puede por medio de su esfuerzo.
La meta de Clotilde es seguir trabajando para poder ayudar a los suyos, y es por eso que solicita este crédito para la compra de insumos que necesita para poder seguir trabajando, como ser telas, hijos, botones y demás.
texts.en:
The "Mujeres Sobresalientes" ("Outstanding Women") communal bank is in its third cycle. With 16 members, it is a group that stands out in the neighborhood for being very united, supportive, and responsible. They all do different work.

One of the members is Clotilde, who is an excellent dressmaker. Through her work, she is moving ahead. She is a person who has always worked and she is not afraid to fight to give her family everything she can through her efforts.

Clotilde's goal is to continue working to help her loved ones. That is why she is asking for this loan to buy supplies that she needs in order to be able to continue working, such as fabric, thread, buttons, and other items.

loans.use: to buy fabric, thread, buttons, etc.

loans.name: Penina

texts.en:
Penina is a 48-year-old farmer in Nkubu county in Kenya, where she lives with her husband and four children. None of her children are still in school since they are all adults. She has been farming for the past 10 years, producing milk, tea and cereals that she sells at a nearby market in her area.

She is requesting a loan of 52,500 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow, which will help her increase her income and boost her living standards. She hopes to expand her dairy farming business in the next five years.

Pests and disease are her major challenges in farming.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: C7851 Abakangukiramajyambere Group

texts.en:
Celestin is 30 years old and is married with one child, who is four years old, and he takes care of three relatives. He sells rice in his business, which is open from 6:00 a.m. until 1:00 p.m. every weekday. Celestin has six years of experience in this business. 

He is the leader of his group, which is called C7851 Abakangukiramajyambere in the local language. In the photo, he is the one sitting down. 

Celestin has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to cultivate a large quantity of rice for resale. With this profit, Celestin will save money for the future, to pay school fees and re-invest in his business.

loans.use: To cultivate a large quantity of rice for resale.

loans.name: Bahati

texts.en: After successfully repaying her previous loan, Bahati is requesting a loan in the amount of 20,000 KES to pay school fees for her children. She is grateful for the previous loan because it helped her to expand her business and improve her income which allowed her to improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Yanuarius

texts.en:
Yanuarius, a 42-year-old man, is married to Imelda, who is 40 years old. They are blessed with four children: Lili, 22, married; Alfonsius, 20; Anggi, 13, and Chandra, 8. Anggi and Chandra are both attending school. 

Yanuarius has been running a sewing business since 2004. He has regular customers, so he should meet their orders in a timely way. Customers have asked him to buy fabric for them, but he does not have enough capital to do so. Therefore, he has requested a loan of 4,500,000 IDR from TLM. The loan will be spent on fabric and yarn of various colors. 

Currently, Yanuarius is in his second loan cycle. He has a good repayment record since he joined the TLM program.

loans.use: to buy fabric and yarn of various colors.

loans.name: Imani

texts.en: After successfully repaying her previous loan, Imani is requesting a loan amounting to 50,000 KES to expand her business and buy materials for making dresses, such as zippers, thread, and needles. She is grateful for the previous loan.

loans.use: to buy zippers, thread, and needles for making dresses

loans.name: Pamoja Group

texts.en:
Leonita is a member of Pamoja Group in Kakamega south district. She is pictured with ten One Acre Fund farmers, nine women and one man. Leonita is standing on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for cultivating half an acre of maize, millet, and sorghum. Leonita first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2009 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Leonita joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and to grow enough food for her family.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Leonita was only able to harvest three bags of maize per half acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains of 2009, she was able to harvest eight bags per half acre! She plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school. Leonita’s group members will each receive input loans for a half acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total they will receive inputs for five acres of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum

loans.name: Muchui

texts.en:
Muchui is aged 41 years and a farmer in Nkubu county, Kenya, where he lives with his wife and two children. Both of the children are schooling. Muchui has been in farming for 15 years, producing cereal grains, milk and horticultural crops, which he sells at the local market in his area.

He is requesting to borrow 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo, to purchase irrigation equipment. Irrigation will help him to improve his production, in case the rain is not enough for his crops. He will use the profits of his work to educate his children. He intends to buy a car for transporting his produce, within the next five years. Drought, pests and diseases are his major challenges in farming.

Muchui is grateful for the way Juhudi Kilimo is fast in processing loans.

loans.use: To purchase irrigation equipment

loans.name: Dessy

texts.en:
Dessy is a 35-year-old seamstress. She is married to Roni, age 40. She lives with her husband and their three children: Brian, 11, Jati, 9, and Abi, 6 years old. The children are all attending school. 

Dessy has been running her sewing business since 2001, helping to support the family. Last year, she initiated a poultry business, using her own savings. She thinks that the poultry business can help her to meet the family's needs. In order to improve the poultry business, and to repair her hemming machine, which is broken, she applied for a loan from TLM in the amount of IDR 3,000,000. She plans to buy a box of chicks and to repair the broken hemming machine, with the loan funds. Dessy hopes that the businesses will run well, so she can repay the TLM loan and  increase the income available for family needs.

loans.use: to repair her broken hemming machine, and to buy a box of chicks for her new poultry business.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en: Saumu received her previous loan, which had a great positive impact to her business. She increased the rents she charges, but she was still able to get tenants. Now, she is applying for a subsequent loan, in the amount of KES 30,000, to make repairs to the rental house.

loans.use: to make repairs to the rental house.

loans.name: Malkia Group

texts.en:
Philice is a member of Malkia Group, in Kakamega South District. She is one of the 18 One Acre Fund farmers pictured, 10 women and 8 men. Philice is standing on the right, with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. Philice is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, and to get the best input prices.

Philice managed to harvest three bags of maize on one acre of land, last year.  As a One Acre Fund farmer, she hopes to harvest more. She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest, to send her children to school and to save for the future. For the 2013 Long Rains season, the members of Malkia Group will take input loans of ½ acre, each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on nine acres of land.

(The field officer is standing on the left side of the photo.)

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Inuka Group

texts.en:
Melisa is a member of Inuka Group, which is comprised of 21 farmers and is located in Kakamega South District. Melisa is pictured on the right, with her hand raised. She is pictured amongst the 9 men and 12 women of her group. She will receive inputs on credit, capable of planting ½ an acre with sorghum, millet, and maize. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Melisa’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year, in order to grow enough food for the family and learn more farming skills.

Melisa thought her harvest last year was poor. She hopes that as a One Acre Fund farmer, she can have an excellent harvest this year. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and to save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each member of Inuka Group will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs, on credit. In total, the group will receive 10.5 acres' worth of inputs, on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius, 38, is a farmer in Nkubu County, Kenya, where he lives with his wife and two children who are both in school. He and has been practicing mixed farming for the past ten years, producing beans, milk, avocados, coffee, peas and tea, which he sells to the people in his local area. He owns a motor bike for transportation as an additional source of income.

He is requesting 20,000 KES loan from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase dairy goats that will produce more milk  and give him more income to be able to uplift his living standards and pay for his children's schooling. He plans to buy a milk cooler to help him supply milk in the market in the next five years.

The high cost of feed and poor road networks are his major challenges in farming.

He is thankful to Juhudi Kilimo for enabling him boost his production.

loans.use: to purchase dairy goats.

loans.name: Santa Librada Group

texts.es:
El grupo llamado Santa Librada está en su ciclo número 4, y con el trabajo en conjunto de todas y con la unión que demuestran quieren salir adelante. Son mujeres jefas de familia que quieren salir adelante y ayudar a sus hijos y familiares.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Celina, quien en su última encuesta mostró un nivel de pobreza dentro del nivel uno, por debajo de la línea de pobreza, tiene un ingreso muy módico, y con ello trata de poder ayudar a su familia. Por medio de la costura que es su único medio, está saliendo adelante y trata de crecer.
Solicita de esta ayuda para la compra de telas e hilos, ya que con esto podrá seguir trabajando e invirtiendo en su plan de negocios para poder seguir creciendo.
texts.en:
The Santa Librada group is in its 4th cycle, and with the work of all of them together and the unity they demonstrate, they want to move ahead. They are heads of household who want to move forward and help their children and families.

One of the members is Celina, who when last surveyed showed level one poverty, under the poverty line. She has a very modest income, and with it she tries to be able to help her family. Through the sewing that is her only source of income, she is moving ahead and tries to grow.

She is asking for this help in order to buy fabric and thread, since with this she will be able to continue working and investing in her business plan to be able to continue growing.

loans.use: to buy fabric and thread

loans.name: Abadahemukirana C20006 Group

texts.en:
Consolee is 40 years old, married, and has five children, aged between 8 and 20 years. Consolee has been in the business of selling rice for four years. Her rice business is open from 6:30 A.M. to 1:00 P.M. every day, except in the weekend. Consolee is the leader of a group called Abadahemukirana C20006 in the local language; she is the one raising her hand in the picture. 

Consolee has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company, in order to purchase fertilizer for cultivating a large quantity of rice for sale. She will use any profits to save for her future and to re-invest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for cultivating a large quantity of rice for sale.

loans.name: Sabasaba Group

texts.en:
James is a member of Sabasaba Group from Kakamega South District. He is pictured with 14 One Acre Fund farmers: ten women and four men. James is standing on the right with his hand raised. He is receiving an input loan for a ½ acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. James first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. James joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and to grow enough food for his family.

James reports that, before One Acre Fund, he was able to grow about two bags of maize per acre but, with his One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, he harvested 10 bags per acre. He plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send his children to school and save for the future. 

For the 2013 Long Rains season, James’ group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 7 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy construction materials

loans.name: Wakongwe Group

texts.en:
Wakongwe is a group of 19 farmers from Kakamega South District represented by Ibrahim. The group has 17 women and 2 men. Ibrahim is on the right of the photo with his hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to him on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of maize, millet and sorghum. Ibrahim joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2011 and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. Ibrahim joined One Acre Fund so that he could grow enough food for the family and use increased profits to send his children to school.

Ibrahim described his harvest as very good last year but believes he can have an even better one this year. He hopes that his profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send his children to school and save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Ibrahim’s group will receive 9.5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: C7854 Intwari Group

texts.en:
Odette is 37 years old and married with one child, who is 19 years old. She owns an agriculture business that sells rice, and her business is open from 6 am to 1 pm each week, except for the weekend. 

Odette is the leader of a group that is called "C7854 Intwari" locally, which means "Hero" in English. She is the one in the photo with a bag in her hand. She has seven years of experience in her work, and she currently employs four people to help her. 

Odette has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to cultivate large quantities of rice for sale. With any profits, she will be able to save for her future, pay school fees for her children, and renovate her house.

loans.use: to cultivate large quantities of rice for sale.

loans.name: Neema Group

texts.en:
Jairus is a member of Neema Group in Kakamega South District. He is pictured with 14 One Acre Fund farmers, 11 women and three men. Jairus is standing on the right with his hand raised. He is receiving an input loan for half an acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. Jairus first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2011 Long Rains season and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Jairus joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and use the increased profits to send his children to school.

Jairus described his harvest as good last year, but believes he can have an even better one this year. He plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send his children to school and save for the future. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Jairus’s group members will take input loans of half an acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 7 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Mwero

texts.en: Mwero is asking for a second loan after successful repayment of the previous loan. He is very grateful for the loan which had a positive impact on his business. He was able to expand his business boundary in the market, and he has been able to increase his regular customers. He is requesting a loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to buy ten sacks of sugar and five sacks of maize and bundles of wheat flour.

loans.use: to buy ten sacks of sugar and five sacks of maize and bundles of wheat flour.

loans.name: Muleko Group

texts.en:
Muleko is a group of 10 farmers in Kakamega South District represented by Luka. The group has six women and four men. Luka is on the right of the photo with his hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to him on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant half an acre of maize, millet and sorghum. Luka joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2010 season, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. Luka joined One Acre Fund so that he could gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and access the best input prices.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Luka was only able to harvest one bag of maize per half acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, he was able to harvest five bags per half acre. He hopes that his profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send his children to school and save for the future. Luka’s group members will each receive input loans of half an acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total they will receive inputs for 5 acres of maize and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Athumani

texts.en: Athumani is a 35-year-old man, married with four children, ages 12, 8, 14 and10, all living together in Tiribe, Kenya. His monthly major expenditures are fees payment and food for his family. He owns his own house – no cost for rental payment. He earns his living from a poultry business which he runs. He keeps poultry and sells the eggs to schools and hotels near his home. Due to an increase in demand for eggs, he is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more poultry. He is grateful for the opportunity.

loans.use: to buy more poultry.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is single with two children. Both of them go to school. She lives in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

Rose sells green bananas and has been in this business for two years. Her major challenges include transportation and seasonality. She has applied for a loan of 600,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more bunches of green bananas for her business. She hopes to own a banana plantation and also build her own house.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of green bananas

loans.name: Ebeneza Group

texts.en:
Margaret’s group has 13 farmers and is located in Kakamega South District. Margaret is pictured on the right of Ebeneza Group with her hand raised. She is pictured among the four men and nine women of her group. She will receive a loan enabling her to plant 1/2 an acre with sorghum, millet, and maize. Margaret first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2010 Long Rains season and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Margaret joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and to use increased profits to send her children to school.
Margaret reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about one bag of maize per 1/2 acre, but, with her One Acre Fund loan during Long Rains 2012, she harvested seven bags per 1/2 acre. She plans to use future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and to save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive 1/2 an acre of agricultural supplies on credit. Margaret’s group will receive 6.5 acres worth of supplies on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Mgala

texts.en:
Mgala is a 42-year-old man. He is married to Mary and blessed with two children, ages 15 and 17, a boy and a girl who are both in school. He lives in Tiribe, Kenya in his own home. His major monthly expenditure is school fees for his children.
He owns a retail shop in which he sells household goods. He has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to buy sacks of sugar and maize flour and bundles of wheat flour.

loans.use: to buy sacks of sugar and maize flour and bundles of wheat flour.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is married with three children. Only two of them go to school. She also takes care of additional family (old parents). She lives in her own house, but the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

Agnes has a beauty salon and has been in this business for three years. She generates additional income by selling tomatoes, onions and oranges and also from rental houses. She works at the market five days out of every week. Her major business challenges include thieves, the ever increasing price of cosmetics in Uganda and seasonality. 

Agnes has applied for a loan of 500,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more boxes of cream relaxers, weaves and braids. She hopes to educate her children up to university, own a fully stocked beauty salon, and also to build more rental rooms.

loans.use: to buy more boxes of cream relaxers, weaves and braids

loans.name: Bemchenga

texts.en:
Bemchenga is 41 years old and is a hardworking entrepreneur. He is married and has three children. He lives in Likoni, Kenya with his family in his own house. School fee payments are his major monthly expenditure. He owns a kiosk shop where he sells commonly-used household goods.
He has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to buy a carton of soap, bundles of wheat flour, and a sack of maize flour.

loans.use: to buy a carton of soap, bundles of wheat flour, and a sack of maize flour.

loans.name: Susanna

texts.en:
Susanna is 60 years old. She is a widow and lives in the city of Ijevan with her son. As she confessed, she has had a hard life. Her husband died a long time ago, and so she has raised her son alone without any support.
Susanna is a technologist. She graduated from the Industrial College of Ijevan. While Armenia was under Soviet rule, she worked in Ijevan factories and had a good reputation as a technologist. But after the collapse of the Soviet Union, many factories in Ijevan closed, and Susanna became jobless. She appeared to be in a stalemate, but she wanted to ensure the well-being of her family. She started selling clothes and shoes by renting a place in an Ijevan market. Her son helps her with the business. Twice a month, Susanna’s son buys shoes and clothes from Yerevan wholesale markets and transports them to their stall in Ijevan to resell.
For the spring trading season, Susanna needs a loan of about 600,000 AMD to buy a new spring ladies’ shoe collection and a new clothes assortment for women. This loan will help her to increase their trading income and will help Susanna to realize her big dream – to organize her son’s wedding party.

loans.use: to buy a new spring ladies’ shoe collection and a new clothes assortment for women.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 28-year-old married man with two children. He has worked as a decorator for twelve years. His business is going really well in his local region, but he needs help to expand the area he can work in. 

Ali has applied for a youth loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua to buy a car. This will help him to expand the area he can cover with his painting business, and also to transport his tools and machines from job to job. 

Ali is well known in his local area, and has a good reputation.  He has a talent for business and works very hard to keep customers loyal by providing them with the best service possible. This is Ali's first loan, and he hopes that his future relationship with Al Majmoua will improve his family's social and financial situation. He wants to make sure that they will have the best education, and he also wants to keep expanding his business.

loans.use: To buy a car, necessary for his business expansion

loans.name: Ushindi Group

texts.en:
Bornice is the farmer pictured on the right of the photo with her hand raised. She is one of the twenty farmers in the Ushindi Group, one man and nineteen women.  Bornice will recive a loan of the required inputs to plant half an acre with sorghum, millet and maize.  She first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains, and she is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Bornice joined One Acre Fund to grow enough food for her family.

Bornice described her harvest as very good last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school, and invest in cows. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive half an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Bornice’s group will therefore receive ten acres worth of inputs on credit in total.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is married with four children, but only three of her children go to school. She is also responsible for two additional family members, her sister and brother. She has owned and managed a business selling charcoal for the last ten years. Grace is a hard worker, she works seven days a week and sells to both retail and wholesale customers. Her major business challenges include transportation, seasonality and theft. Grace lives in her own house with her family, and they have electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses includes medication, feeding the family and utility bills. 

Grace has applied for a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal. She would love to own a delivery van to help with transporting her charcoal, and to focus on selling to wholesale clients only.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 44 years old, married to Ruth, and a father of six children aged between five and seventeen years old. He works as a farmer cultivating wheat and potatoes.  James has been in this business for 20 years, and earns a monthly income of 35,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES).

James has asked for his fifth loan of KES 80,000, which will help him to buy seedlings and fertilizers. He plans to use anticipated profits to plough back to the business for expansion. His dream is to be a successful farmer.

loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizers

loans.name: Sadick

texts.en:
Sadick is asking for a subsequent loan after successfully repaying his previous loan. He is grateful for the support from the loan because he was able to improve his income and living standards.

He is asking for a loan of 80,000 Kenyan Shillings to expand his business and buy cattle for resale, as demand has increased and selling goats is no longer enough.

loans.use: to expand his business and buy cattle for resale to meet increased demand.

loans.name: Pukers Group

texts.en:
Pukers is a group of 20 farmers in the Kakamega South District of Kenya who are represented by Francis, pictured on the right of the photo with his hand raised. The group has twelve women and six men.

With Francis' loan, he will receive the necessary materials to plant half an acre of maize, millet and sorghum. Francis joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains season of 2007, and is now enrolling in the 2013 Long Rains season. He became a member of the fund so that he could gain access to hybrid seeds and fertilizers and use the increased profits for his children's education.

Francis described his harvest as very good last year, but believes he can have an even better one this year. He hopes that his profits can be used to send his children to school and to save for the future. Francis' group members will each receive input loans for half an acre of farming. In total they will receive materials for nine acres of maize and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Upendo Group

texts.en:
Linus is a member of Upendo Group in Kakamega South District. He is pictured as one of 16 One Acre Fund farmers, 13 women and 3 men. Linus is standing on the right with his hand raised. He is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. Linus first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2007 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season.  Linus joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and access the best input prices.

Linus described his harvest as very good last year, but believes he can have an even better one this year. He plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send his children to school and perhaps invest in another business. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Linus’ group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on eight acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Jared

texts.en:
Jared is 37 years old, married to Maureen, and a father of three children aged seven, six and four years old. His wife operates a beauty salon while he operates a motorcycle transport business.

He has acquired his fourth top up loan from KADET limited of 100,000 KES which he will use to repair his motorcycle and also to buy a hair dryer for use in his wife's beauty shop. He will use the anticipated proceeds from the businesses to educate his children. He hopes to open another business in future.

loans.use: to repair his motorcycle and to buy a hair dryer for use in his wife's beauty salon.

loans.name: Tumaini Group

texts.en:
Mellisah is a member of Tumaini Group in Kakamega South District. She is pictured as one of 14 One Acre Fund farmers, 12 women and 2 men. Mellisah is standing on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. Mellisah joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2011, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. Mellisah joined One Acre Fund so that she could use increased profits to send her children to school and gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer.

Mellisah reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about one bag of maize per ½ acre, but with her One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, she harvested 11 bags per acre! She plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and save for the future. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Mellisah’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on seven acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a 39-year-old farmer in Nkubu county in Kenya where she lives with her husband and two children, both of whom attend school. She has been farming for ten years, producing cereals and horticultural crops which she sells at the local market.

She is requesting a loan of 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase irrigation equipment that will help her in improving her production in case there is not enough rain for her crops. She intends to be a prominent farmer in her area in the next five years. Lack of rainfall, pests and diseases are her major challenges in farming.

loans.use: to purchase irrigation equipment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fabrics, shoes, rings, bracelets and necklaces for resale.

loans.name: Israa

texts.en:
Israa is an 18-year-old single woman, who has been working as a hair dresser since 2010. She is well known in the region because of the excellent service she provides to please her customers.

Israa is a hard worker who puts so much effort into improving her living and helping her parents to cover their expenses. She is applying for a YOUTH LOAN from Kiva partner Al Majmoua, in order to start a new business to increase her income. She will start selling clothes from her house and will work hard to open a shop in the future that will be a beauty salon and a clothes shop, until she can open separate shops in the near future.

loans.use: To start a new business to improve her life

loans.name: Salma

texts.en: Salma is a food vendor from Kisauni, Kenya. She is a married woman and a mother of three children. Salma is asking for a loan to buy ingredients such as meat, vegetables, seasonings, cooking oil and flour. This will enable her to cook and sell more food to the people in her area thus increasing her sales and income. Salma hopes to make her business successful and sustainable in the future. Moreover, she wants to continue to support her children's schooling.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as meat, vegetables, seasonings, cooking oil and flour.

loans.name: Shiungulukha Group

texts.en:
Shiungulukha Group is located in Kakamega South District. It is a group of 13 women and 4 men led by Maliana pictured on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation. Maliana first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2010 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Maliana joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family.

Maliana described her harvest as good last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year. She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school and save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Maliana’s group will receive 8 1/2 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase materials for constructing a zero grazing unit

loans.name: Baina

texts.en:
Baina is a hard-working married woman. She operates a general store selling charcoal. She and her husband are the responsible parents of three children, and her store is the only source of income for the family.

At present, the stock of her business is almost depleted. For this reason, she has requested a loan from Kiva partner Yehu Microfinance, which she will use to purchase sacks of charcoal for the store. This investment will help her to continue her small business and to satisfy the demands of her clients.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for her store.

loans.name: Milly

texts.en: Milly is married with two children and both her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (elderly parents). She knits sweaters and has been in this business for 5 years. She has applied for a loan from MCDTSACCO to buy more threads and additional needles for the knitting machine. Her major customers are schools in the area.  She sells on wholesale only and works seven days a week. Her major business challenges includes transportation of threads from Kampala city to her home and also some schools take time to pay back hence inconveniencing her work. She aspires to own a big factory for making sweaters and also to educate her children up to university. She resides in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more threads and needles for knitting sweaters.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more fertilizer for cultivating large quantities of rice for resale.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a resident of Kisauni, Kenya. She is a charcoal seller and has been doing this business for four years. Fatuma is married and the mother of two children.

Fatuma is asking for a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings to purchase new stock of charcoal to sell.
Despite the challenge of the high cost of transportation, Fatuma believes the business has a future and in addition to getting the income to educate her children, she looks forward to owning a vehicle (canter) to transport charcoal to other areas.

loans.use: to purchase new stock of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Coumba

texts.fr: Madame Coumba  est réside  au Sénégal. C’est une femme mariée  qui exerce l’activité de commerce   pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Elle évolue depuis plus de 30 vans dans la vente de produits détergents (savon en poudre, eau de javel …etc.) et de produits alimentaires tels que piment, poivre. Elle sollicite au  guichet  de l’U-IMCEC où elle est membre, un prêt d’un montant de 100.000 francs CFA en vue de renforcer  son fond de roulement et développer son activité de commerce.  Elle espère accroitre ses bénéfices  pour mieux faire face a ses charges familiales, notamment le règlement des paiements  de factures d’eau et d’électricité.  Son projet futur est de terminer  la construction de sa maison.
texts.en: Mrs Coumba lives in Senegal. She is  married and performs commercial activity to meet her family's needs. For over 30 years she has been selling detergent (soap powder, bleach ... etc) and food products such as chili, pepper. She requests a loan of 100.000 CFA francs from the U-IMCEC office where she is a member in order to reinforce her working capital and develop her business. She hopes to increase her profits to help her cope with her family expenses, in particular to pay her water and electricity bills. Her project for the future is to finish the construction of her home.

loans.use: to buy detergents, pepper and chili for resale.

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
Jenifer is a 25-year-old farmer in Nkubu County where she lives with her husband and two children, only one has started school.  She has been in mixed farming for the past twelve years producing milk and vegetables which she sells to the people around her local area.

She is requesting a 20,000 KES loan from Juhudi kilimo to purchase water tanks that will help her in irrigating her crops. She will be in a position to get better produce that will give her more income to help her be able to take care of her family’s needs comfortably.  She plans to have opened a fully equipped veterinary shop in the next five years.

Drought, pests and diseases are her major challenges in farming.
Jenifer is happy with the affordable interest rates offered by Juhudi Kilimo.

loans.use: to purchase water tanks for irrigation.

loans.name: Callen

texts.en:
Callen is 42 years old, a hardworking lady, married to Patrick, and a mother of four children aged between 26 and 12 years old. She operates a food stall and has been in the business for the last ten years earning a monthly income of KES. 50,000.

She has acquired a sixth loan of KES.100,000 to facilitate setting up a small hotel due to the increased demand.

She hopes to use the proceeds to plough back into the business for expansion. Her hope and dream is to own a large hotel.

loans.use: to set up a small hotel.

loans.name: Salwa

texts.en:
Salwa is a 36-year-old single woman who has been working since 2006 in a convenience store, which she has developed over time. She has started a small snack stand as a part of the store, which she loves a lot and is working hard to improve. Thus today she is applying for a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua in order to make small changes to her shop. She will put in a new aluminum and glass door frame, a table for the snacks, and she will increase her stock of merchandise. 

Salwa is trusted and supported by all of her customers, and she loves to serve them as well as she can. Her shop is located in a Palestinian camp, and she is very happy that she serves her customers in a very pleasant way.

loans.use: To put in a new door frame and a table for snacks in her convenience store, and to buy more merchandise

loans.name: Amani Group

texts.en:
Alice is pictured on the right with her hand raised among her Amani Group members. The 21 of them, 13 women and 8 men, are farmers in Kakamega South District. Farming inputs will be delivered to her on credit, consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of maize, millet, and sorghum. Alice joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2009, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. Alice joined One Acre Fund so that she could grow enough food for the family and use increased profits to send her children to school.

Alice reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about 6 bags of maize per 1½ acres, but with her One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, she harvested 37 bags per 1 1/2 acres! she plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and buy a cow. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Alice’s group will receive 10 1/2 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Elchin

texts.en: Elchin has been an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) from Fizuli city, but now he lives in the Fuzuli region with his family. He is married and has a child. Elchin is 24 years old. He has had his beauty salon for 2 years. Now he needs a 2,000 AZN loan to buy some new materials to repair his salon. He wants to improve his business. You can see in the photo that his salon is not in good condition.

loans.use: to buy some new materials to repair his salon.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is age twenty-eight and a farmer in Nkubu county where she lives with her husband and two children, only one of whom has started schooling. She has been practicing mixed farming for the past four years, producing vegetables, milk, bananas and other fruits which she sells at the local market.

She is requesting a 20,000 KES loan from Juhudi kilimo to purchase pigs from which she will sell the meat to get more income. That will help her improve her family’s livelihood and enable her to pay school fees for her children with some ease. She plans to have opened a slaughter house for pork in the next five years.

Insecurity is her major challenge in farming. Elizabeth says Juhudi kilimo is the best micro-finance institution for small scale farmers.

loans.use: To purchase pigs for pork.

loans.name: Jitegemee Group

texts.en:
Christine is a member of the Jitegemee Group in Kakamega South District. She is pictured with 11 One Acre Fund farmers, 7 women and 4 men. Christine is standing on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation. Christine first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2009 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer.

Christine described her harvest as good last year as a One Acre Fund farmer and hopes for another good year in the 2013 Long Rains season. She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school and buy a cow. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Christine’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 5 1/2 acres of land.  

The field officer is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Rebecca's Group

texts.en: Rebecca is a 28-year-old mother of two and a tailor. Her husband is an electrician. Rebecca sees the KOMAZA microforestry program "as an investment for the future for my kids." With the income from her tree farm, Rebecca intends to send her children to school without financial strain, build a permanent home with electricity and improve her tailoring business. Also pictured with the group of nine is Dzame, who showed a great deal of interest in the KOMAZA tree-planting program but was unable to commit her family's time to an additional agricultural venture this season.

loans.use: to purchase tree farm supplies such as eucalyptus seedlings and fertilizer, as well as to pay for technical training and maintenance support.

loans.name: Djahid

texts.en: Djahid is married and has 2 children. He has been an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) from occupied territories (Fizuli city). Now he lives in the Fuzuli region with his family. Djahid has been in this business for 3 years. Now he needs a 2,000 AZN (Azerbaijani New Manat) to buy livestock for his business. Djahid is 27 years old.

loans.use: to buy livestock.

loans.name: Dam

texts.en:
Dam was born in 1950. She has two children who are adults. Her husband is a worker. Dam is a worker and a farmer to earn a living. Her income is about 6,500,000 VND. Her family’s total earnings are about 10,000,000 VND per month. 

She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2010. In the last cycle she borrowed 7,840,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 9,632,000 VND to buy food for pigs.

loans.use: to buy food for pigs.

loans.name: Lien

texts.en:
Lien was born in 1988. She has two little children. She and her husband are carpenters and farmers to earn a living. She has done this job for 5 years. Her income is about 6,000,000 dong [VND]. Her family’s total earnings are about 16,000,000 VND per month. 
	
She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2010. In the last cycle she borrowed 9,184,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, Lien would like to borrow 10,080,000 VND to buy wood for doing carpentry and to buy food for pigs. She always wants to raise her children up well and upgrade her carpentry workshop.

loans.use: to buy wood for doing carpentry and to buy food for pigs.

loans.name: Anifa

texts.en:
Anifa is a married woman who has no children. She has a well-stocked food pantry in her home from which she sells to her neighbors and occasional customers. She offers beverages, sugar, rice, baked goods and other basic household necessities. By stocking her business with her own vegetables, she is able to generate a better profit.

The loan she is requesting will be used to buy products in bulk, such as meat, beverages, canned goods and other items. With the end of the year approaching, she wants to increase her stock since prices go up during this time. She wants to continue offering affordable prices to her customers.

loans.use: to buy products in bulk, such as meat, beverages, canned goods, and other items.

loans.name: Thoa

texts.en:
Thoa was born in 1985. She has three daughters. Her oldest child is in the 1st grade. Two younger daughters are too young for school. Her husband and she are carpenters. Her income is about 5,000,000 dong [VND]. Her family’s total earnings are about 10,000,000 VND per month.
She joined SEDA's credit program in 2013. In this first loan cycle, she would like to borrow 5,152,000 VND to buy carpentry tools such as chisels and saws. She hopes to raise her children well and enlarge her wood workshop.

loans.use: to buy carpentry tools such as chisels and saws.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married and has four children, all of whom attend school. She is a tailor who, over time and after getting experience, opened her own workshop. She began with a single sewing machine and now has two. Her husband is a technician and between them they have provided everything for their children.

In the future, her goal is to expand her workshop and to buy more machines and provide jobs for others. She is applying for this loan so that she can buy fabric and thread to keep working and meeting her customers’ needs.

loans.use: to buy fabric and thread for her sewing.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is married and lives with her three children. She learnt to be a dressmaker by working as a seamstress in a factory producing wind proof jackets. She was able to save money over the years, and as a result, buy a sewing machine and start up her business. At the present time, she is one of the best known people for sewing articles of clothing, jackets, curtains, sheets, etc.
The loan that Amina has applied for is intended for the purchase of fabrics and other articles, so as to be able to satisfy her customer’s wishes. In this way, she intends to offer them better services.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and other articles to aid in her tailoring business.

loans.name: Tai

texts.en:
Tai was born in 1963. He has two children who are workers. His wife sells rice to earn a living. Her income is about 4,000,000 dong [VND]. Tai raises pigs to earn a living. He gets about 3,500,000 VND per month. His family’s total earnings are about 10,000,000 VND per month.
He has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2008. In the last cycle he borrowed 9,184,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, he would like to borrow 10,080,000 VND to buy food for pigs. He wants to enlarge his farm of pigs.

loans.use: to buy food for his pigs.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet from Kisauni, is married and has two children. She is a hairdresser and she also sells sewing supplies and shoes. She has loyal customers, because she always gives good service.

She is a hardworking person, responsible and very honest. She started to work in a hair salon as a secretary and her dream was to become a professional and to have her own salon. With time, sacrifice and hard work she was able to reach her goal.
She is now requesting a loan to expand her beauty salon and in this way to be able to continue growing and to offer better services to her customers.

loans.use: to expand her beauty salon.

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris is from Kisauni, and operates a small hair salon. She wants to remodel her salon in order to offer her clients a more comfortable environment, and generate more income to help support her family. She is requesting this loan in order to help grow her business.

She is a very hardworking person with a persistent spirit and attitude. She has much experience in her field, and knows what she is doing. Her goal is to one day have a large beauty salon, and to be widely known for her talent. She is grateful for this opportunity, and believes that the support will be a great help to her.

loans.use: to remodel her beauty salon.

loans.name: Trang

texts.en:
Trang was born in 1990. She has two daughters who are a four and two years old. Her husband is a carpenter and earns about 4,000,000 VND per month. Trang also is a carpenter. Her income is about 3,000,000 VND. She has done this job for 4 years. Her family’s total earnings are about 7,000,000 VND per month.

She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2011. In the last cycle she borrowed 7,392,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,288,000 VND to buy wood for her carpentry workshop. She aspires to raise her children well.

loans.use: to buy wood for her carpentry workshop.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose sells a variety of products in her store. Managing her business involves offering merchandise and accepting payments over both the short and long term. This type of work allows her to provide jobs to other people since she has many customers.

Rose is an entrepreneur who strives every day to improve the stability of her family. Her objective going forward is to establish a wholesale shop for the delivery of her merchandise. She is requesting this loan so that she can buy a variety of products to sell. This will enable her to continue working and improve the range she can offer to her customers.

loans.use: to buy a variety of merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Luong's Group

texts.en:
Luong was born in 1967. She has two children who are a worker and a supermarket cashier. Her husband is dead. Luong collects iron scrap to earn a living. She gains from her job 3,500,000 VND a month. Her family’s total earnings are about 10,000,000 VND per month.
She joined SEDA's credit program in 2013. In this first loan cycle, she would like to borrow 5,152,000 VND to buy more iron scraps to recycle. She wants to save more money for her family.

Other members which are part of Luong's group include the following:
Hong is 55 years old. She has a child. She wants to borrow 5,152,000 VND to raise chikens.
Tam is 22 years old. She has a child. She wants to borrow 5,152,000 VND to sell food in the market.
Thanh is 26 years old. He has two children. He wants to borrow 5,152,000 VND to buy food for his pigs.

loans.use: to buy more iron scraps to recycle.

loans.name: Kibibi

texts.en:
Kibibi is a widow, has five children, and lives in Kisauni. She has a well-stocked grocery store. She says she started with a small store and later changed areas and now has her grocery store. It has gone very well for her, with regular customers because of her longevity in the location.

She's requesting the loan to buy beverages, canned goods, vegetables, and other supplies for her business because these are the most popular.
She's grateful for the help she gets because it will be very useful to her.

loans.use: to buy beverages, canned goods, vegetables, and other supplies for her store.

loans.name: The Star Group

texts.en:
Hadiatu is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Hadiatu was born in Yoni, in northern Sierra Leone 28 years ago. She is married to a carpenter and the couple has 2 children who are attending primary school. Hadiatu sells ready-to-wear-clothes and has been doing this business for many years now.

With the help of this loan, Hadiatu and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. Hadiatu will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to buy ready-to-wear-clothes in a larger quantity to add to her current stock for sale.

loans.use: to buy ready-to-wear-clothes in a larger quantity to add to her current stock for sale.

loans.name: Tamemkoh Group

texts.en:
Adama is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Adama was born in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone 27 years ago. She is married to a tailor and the couple has 2 children who are attending primary school. Adama sells ready-to-wear-clothes and has been doing this business for many years now.
With the help of this loan, Adama and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. Adama will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to buy ready-to-wear-clothes in a larger quantity to have for sale.

loans.use: to buy ready-to-wear-clothes in a larger quantityto have for sale.

loans.name: Action Group 2

texts.en:
Marie is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Marie was born in Mile-Ninety-One, in northern Sierra Leone, 41 years ago. She is married to a trader and the couple has 4 children who are attending primary and secondary schools. Marie sells sugar, rice, and other items; she has been doing this business for many years now.

With the help of this loan, Marie and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Marie will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to buy a large quantity of sugar and rice to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy a large quantity of sugar and rice to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a Ghanaian artisan who specializes in transforming natural fibers into elegant handbags. He would like to purchase considerable amounts of raffia rope, jute, threads and lining fabric to increase production.

Paul has been selling through NOVICA since 2009. This is his story:

"My late uncle taught me to weave with corn husks, but after three months, he abandoned the work because it wasn't lucrative. I decided that I would pursue this art and come up with new, attractive designs. Initially, I was creating small bags and customers encouraged me to continue. I work with all kinds of materials – corn husks, plantain leaves, kente cloth, fabric, leather, plywood, foam, raffia, twine and cotton cord. I've had the opportunity to teach over a hundred young people how to weave with corn husks. My ambition is to eventually establish a big workshop to train youths who are interested in this craft and to be able to produce new designs on a larger scale."

"I thank you all for supporting my work with this microcredit. It is much appreciated!"

Use the link below to view Paul's natural fiber handbags on the NOVICA site:

http://www.novica.com/kiva/7206

loans.use: to purchase considerable amounts of raffia rope, jute, threads and lining fabric to increase production.

loans.name: Mario's Group

texts.en:
Mario is 61 years old and lives in Butuay, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is widowed with 3 children. 

Mario has an eatery business and earns approximately 3,500 PHP each month doing this type of work. He has requested a loan to purchase meat, ingredients and other goods for his mini-eatery.

Mario has been a member of PMPC almost 2 years. In the future, Mario hopes to engage in other types of business. Mario is the leader of a 2-person group. Although they borrow as a group, each member of the group has his own business.

loans.use: to purchase meat, ingredients and other goods for his eatery.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to update his equipment.

loans.name: Charlie

texts.en:
When Charlie accepted a driving position at a trucking company four years ago, he never dreamed he would someday venture off on his own as an independent contractor.

“Never in a million years did I think I’d be doing this,” Charlie says.

While it wasn’t his original goal, Charlie has excelled in his work and found his niche. Being self-employed is just the appropriate next step. Charlie will use his Kiva loan to help him purchase his own truck, the primary expense to being an independent contractor. 

Charlie looks forward to the opportunity. He says, for his personality, it’s much more motivating to be paid in the stops and miles versus in hours worked. 

“I love making my own schedule, going to work when I feel like it, and being more independent overall,” he says. 

Charlie was born and raised in New Orleans and although some jobs take him to other locations around Southeast Louisiana, he says he enjoys that most of his days are spent driving around the city, hauling shipping containers on his truck. 

“Being on the road every day, you get to see what’s going on,” he says.  

Charlie is ready to revel in his new freedom as his own boss, but at the same time, he already has his eye on the future. His ultimate goal is to purchase at least two or three additional trucks and hire drivers under him. He likes the idea of creating jobs in the community and helping others get their start in a career he finds rewarding.

To get there, Charlie will be diligently saving his profits. While it can be difficult to put away savings, Charlie says it’s easy when you know exactly what you are going to do with the funds. Despite not envisioning this path four years ago, today Charlie says he knows exactly where he’s going and looks forward to growing his business for years to come.

loans.use: To purchase his own truck for transporting goods

loans.name: Ma. Theresa

texts.en:
Ma. Theresa is 52 years old and lives in Rizal, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is married with three children. 

Ma. Theresa is engaged in the hog fattening business and earns approximately PHP 3,000 each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan to be used in purchasing additional sacks of feed for her hog fattening activity. 

Ma. Theresa joined PMPC just last Dec. 2012. In the future,  Ma. Theresa hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional sacks of feed

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is 59 years old and married with nine children. With two children currently in school, Anita works very hard to provide for them.

Anita runs a business buying and selling charcoal in the Philippines and requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell. She has been in this business for five years.

In the future Anita would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Gaudiosa

texts.en:
Gaudiosa is 52 years old and lives in Gil Sanhez, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is married with six children.

To earn a living, Gaudiosa has a business selling a variety of foods for snacks. She earns about 5000 PHP each month doing this type of work. Gaudiosa has requested a loan to purchase more raw ingredients for her snack vending business.

Gaudiosa has been a member of PMPC for three years. In the future, Gaudiosa would like to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more raw ingredients for her snack vending business

location.town: Liloy-Gil Sanchez, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Sunrise Center Group

texts.en:
Emma is maried with six children. She is 56  years old and lives in the Philippines.

Emma is a farmer and grows pigs to earn a living. She has doing this for 20 years. She requested a loan to purchase more pigs to grow. 

Emma has been  a member of PMPC for six years. In the future, she hopes to buy a car for transporting her pigs.

loans.use: to purchase feed for hog raising

location.town: Pagadian - Lower Bagong Silang  Pagadian City

loans.name: Pilar Jane

texts.en:
Pilar Jane is 25 years old and lives in Namnama, Titay, Zamboanga Sibugay. She is married with two children.

To earn a living, Pilar Jane has a business selling barbecue. She earns about 3000 PHP each month doing this type of work. Pilar Jane has a requested  loan to purchase more meat to cook as barbecue to retail.

Pilar Jane has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, Pilar Jane would like to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more meat to cook as barbecue

loans.name: Edgardo

texts.en:
Edgardo works hard to support his family. He is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Edgardo requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, eggs, soap, snack foods, etc. He has been in this business for six years now.

In the future, Edgardo would like to build and expand his business to secure the financial stability of his family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, eggs, soap, snack foods, etc

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora is married with three children. She is 50 years old and lives in ZNAC, Tampilisan, Zamboanga del Norte.

Aurora owns a store to earn a living and had this business for 10 years. Each month, she earns 3000 PHP doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase more stock  such as toothpaste, soap and other items to sell.

Aurora has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, Aurora hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock  such as toothpaste, soap and other items to sell

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. Elvira has been in this business for 4 years. Elvira earns more income from raising pigs.

She is borrowing 50000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of items like salted egg, soft drinks, sugar, and noodles to sell in her general store business.

Elvira has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of salted egg, soft drinks, sugar, and noodles to sell.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 37 years old and married, with five children who are currently going to school. Erlinda works very hard to provide for them.

Erlinda runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a loan of 15000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of soft drinks, soap, oil, and other groceries needed in her business. Erlinda has been in this business for 5 years.

In the future, Erlinda would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of soft drinks, soap, oil, and other groceries needed in her business.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Evelyn works hard to support her family. She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling livestock.

Evelyn is borrowing 10000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional ingredients and other cooking materials for her food vending business.

Evelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past two loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure the future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients and other cooking materials for her business.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Helen works hard to support her family. She has a motorycle transport business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from farming sugarcane. 

Helen is borrowing 29500 PHP through NWTF to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

Helen has been sustaining her business activities through her past 22 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle business.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda works hard to support her family. Imelda is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Imelda requested a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to purchase items to sell like soap, canned goods, eggs, spices, etc.

Imelda has been in this business for six years now.

In the future, Imelda would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase items to sell like soap, canned goods, eggs, spices, etc.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes is 63 years old and married with six children.

She earns a living by pig fattening in the Philippines. Lourdes is borrowing 29,500 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Lourdes has been pig fattening for two years and also earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is 38 years old and lives in Poblacion, Titay, Zamboanga Sibugay. She is married with two children.

Elsie has a sari-sari (variety) store. She is also an Avon dealer and sells RTW (ready-to-wear) products. She earns approximately 25,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan to purchase more products such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, vinegar and salt to sell.

Elsie has been a member of PMPC since 2012. In the future, Elsie hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more products such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, vinegar and salt to sell.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is married with six children. She is 55 years old and lives in Poblacion, Titay, Zamboanga Sibugay. Elizabeth owns a general store to earn a living and has had this business for 20 years. Each month, she earns 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase more stock for her general store such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, salt, etc.

Elizabeth is a new member of PMPC. In the future, Elizabeth hopes to expand her store.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her general store such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, salt, etc.

loans.name: Ma. Luz

texts.en:
Ma. Luz is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 10,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of items like biscuits, soft drinks, soap, and other groceries to sell in her general store.

Ma. Luz has been in this business for 18 years. She earns additional income by buying and selling livestock and selling Avon.

Ma. Luz has sustained her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure her family's future.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of items like biscuits, soft drinks, and soap to sell.

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn is 45 years old and married with four children. She works hard to provide for her family. Marlyn runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 22,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy stock to sell like eggs, bottled water, sardines, noodles, etc.

Marlyn has borrowed and repaid 10 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 15 years and also earns income from a photocopier. Marlyn hopes to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy stock to sell like eggs, bottled water, sardines, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Merceditha
